Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of Boron and Boride Nanoclusters: Laying the Foundation for New Boron Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms - A Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Lai-Sheng Wang from Brown University of Providence, will carry out fundamental investigations of the structures and bonding of boron clusters and metal boride clusters as a function of size and composition. The objective of this project is to build the foundation and knowledge base to understand the stability and viability of boron-based nanostructures, as well as discovering new forms of boron nanostructures. Three types of boron-related nanoclusters will be investigated: 1) boron clusters containing between 20 to 100 atoms, 2) metal boride clusters, and 3) hydrogenated boron clusters. These clusters will be produced using a laser vaporization supersonic cluster source and characterized by photoelectron spectroscopy. The spectroscopic information will be combined with computational studies to elucidate the structures, stability, and chemical bonding of the boron-based clusters.

Clusters are aggregate of atoms and their structures and properties change with the number of atoms, forming the foundation of nanoscience. The understanding of how the structures and properties of boron clusters change as a function of size will provide information about the viability of boron-based nanomaterials. Metal borides constitute an important class of superhard materials. Fundamental knowledge about how metal atoms bond with boron atoms in metal boride clusters will be valuable in the design of new superhard boride materials. Hydrogenated boron clusters provide opportunities to investigate chemical interactions of hydrogen with boron nanostructures, as well as providing a platform to discover new forms of boron-nanostructures. Through the proposed research, students and postdoctoral fellows will acquire specialized training in the preparation of size-selected clusters and spectroscopic and computational tools to characterize them. The experimental results will be integrated into the classroom for the teaching of physical chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project aimed at a fundamental understanding of boron and metal boride clusters, with the long-term objective of discovering new boron-based nanostructures and nanomaterials.  The experiment involved primarily photoelectron spectroscopy studies of size-selected cluster anions, produced by a laser vaporization supersonic cluster source. Photoelectron spectra contained electronic structure fingerprints for the underlying clusters and were combined with theoretical calculations to provide information about the structure, stability, and chemical bonding of the clusters. The focus of the research was to elucidate the structural transitions of boron nanoclusters as a function of size, laying the foundation for discovering new forms of boron nanostructures. The systematic elucidation of the structures and structural transitions of boron clusters built the knowledge base for understanding the viability and stability of planar (2D) borons, boron nanotubes, and fullerenelike nanostructures.

Two major discoveries were made under this project. The first was the observation of the planar B36 cluster with a hexagonal vacancy, which provided the first experimental evidence for the viability of stable atom-thin 2D borons with hexagonal vacancies and led to the coining of the name “borophene” for this class of novel 2D materials, which have since been synthesized experimentally on inert substrates by several research groups. The second major finding was the all-boron cage cluster, B40, named “borospherene”, which represented the first fullerene-like boron cluster.

Transition metal doped boron clusters were another major focus of this project. The most interesting findings include the observation of the metal-centered tubular boron clusters and large boron clusters with a metal atom doped into the planar boron networks, such as CoB18− and RhB18−. These doped 2D-boron clusters suggested the possibilities of creating metal-doped borophenes with potentially tunable electronic, optical, and magnetic properties. A major perspective article was published in Nature Review Chemistry, which outlined the experimental and theoretical advances of planar doped-boron clusters made under this project and their implications for metalloborophenes. Metalloborophenes may represent a new direction in synthetic 2D materials.

Significant efforts were also devoted to pursue high resolution photoelectron spectroscopy using photoelectron imaging, which yielded vibrational information for the neutral final state. High resolution photoelectron images for B11− and B12− were measured, resulting in rich vibrational information for the neutral B11 and B12 clusters. Calculated vibrational structures for several isomers were compared with the experimental data and confirmed that both neutral clusters are 2D, similar to their respective anions.

            This project allowed the support or partial support of five graduate students, two of whom have obtained their Ph.D. One of them is working in the semiconductor industry and another is pursing postdoctoral research in a national laboratory. The PI organized or co-organized several international meetings in subject areas related to this project. In addition, the PI has given numerous invited talks at international meetings and academic institutions, helping disseminate the research results. The PI was able to integrate research results from this project into the classroom in both introductory chemistry and physical chemistry. The project has created new knowledge of interdisciplinary interests, while simultaneously promoting teaching, training, and learning for both graduate and undergraduate students.
